abstract.p: An electromagnetic device, consisting of a pair of permanent magnets and a non-magnetic coil, has shown its linear advantages for inducing parametric stiffness excitation in the laboratory. The electromagnetic device powered by a DC coil current acts like a mechanical spring with constant stiffness. The effects of design parameters upon the electromagnetic stiffness and its linear operating range (referred as the stiffness characteristics) are important and crucial for the design and usage of the device. Thus, a numerical method, based upon the commercial finite element method (FEM) package ANSYS/Emag, was presented for analyzing the stiffness characteristics of the device with DC coil current. The theory foundation for computing the electromagnetic force using FEM was derived and the program realization in ANSYS was introduced briefly. Two typical examples were chosen to verify the accuracy of the numerical analysis method. Based upon these, the restoring force characteristics of the electromagnetic device with various DC coil currents were obtained utilizing the numerical method. Two important indicators (proportional coefficient between linear stiffness and coil current and linear range of the stiffness) were defined for measuring the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device. Then, the effects of the design parameters (both the electromagnetic and structural parameters) on the two indicators were investigated, respectively. The research results provide useful references for the stiffness design of the electromagnetic device in actual practice.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Dynamical systems mathematically modeled by linear ordinary differential equations with periodic coefficients (or Mathieu–Hill equations) are referred to as parametrically excited systems. This type of system is of great theoretical and practical importance because of its many applications in various fields of science and engineering (Ibrahim 1978a, b).

Using experimental means is one of the important aspects of the research on the dynamic behavior of parametrically excited system. Presently, some methods have been used to achieve the parametric stiffness excitation in the laboratory, such as beams and plates subjected to a periodic axial or in-plane loading (Bolotin 1964; lvan-Ewanowski 1976; Deolasi and Datta 1997), axial moving systems (belt (Pellicano et al. 2004; Michon et al. 2008) and plate (Kartik and Wickert 2008)), a pendulum under two-frequency parametric motion (Yatawara et al. 2006), base excited cantilever beam (Rhoads et al. 2008) or wire (Mullin et al. 2003). In addition, (Belovodsky et al. 2002) described several designs of elastic elements with periodically time-varying elasticity. (Echer 2008) and (Dohnal et al. 2006) respectively gave two ideas for creating a mechanical element with time-dependent stiffness. However, these experimental programs seem to be more difficult to achieve in the laboratory, and the dynamic features of the systems induced by parametric excitation could easily be concealed due to the disturbances of some unavoidable nonlinear effects.

In 2001 and 2004, an electromagnetic device, acting like a spring with alternating stiffness, was developed in experiments by (Chen and Yeh 2001) and (Yeh and Kuo 2004) to induce parametric excitation on cantilever beams. The amplitude and frequency of the parametric stiffness excitation were accurately controlled by the current flowing through the coil of the electromagnetic device. (Chen and Yeh 2001) showed that the device could be easily equipped in the laboratory. Since the excitation force is a non-contact electromagnetic force which acts on the beam in the transverse direction, some nonlinear disturbances induced by the geometric imperfection of the beam and the coupling effects between the excitation mechanism and the beam were effectively avoided. Therefore, the electromagnetic device is a potential good choice in the experimental investigation of parametric instability behavior of various structures with various materials. Recently, (Schmidt et al. 2007) used a similar device to demonstrate the effect of a so-called parametric anti-resonance on a test stand.

As the literature shows, current research mainly focuses upon the realization of parametric stiffness excitation utilizing the AC powered electromagnetic device, while the stiffness characteristics of the device powered by DC source (becomes a spring with constant stiffness) have not attracted sufficient attention. The stiffness characteristics referred in here include two major aspects: (1) the relationship between the DC current through the coil and the linear stiffness of the device; and (2) the effects of design parameters upon the electromagnetic stiffness and its linear operating range. Actually, quantitative study on the first aspect is essential for determining the amplitude of the parametric stiffness excitation; to understand the second aspect is also important and crucial for the design and usage of the device. The electromagnetic stiffness is defined as the increase of restoring force per unit of coil displacement. Thus, the key point for analyzing stiffness characteristics is how to compute the electromagnetic force acting on the coil, which essentially belongs to the static electromagnetic field problem. As the structure of the device is relatively complex, so a finite element method (FEM) is employed to solve the problem. The commercial FEM code ANSYS/Emag (see http://www.ansys.com) has powerful modeling capabilities for the electromagnetic field, and provides multiple types of formulations for the static analysis, such as the magnetic scalar potential (MSP) formulation, the magnetic vector potential (MVP) formulation and the edge formulation.

Thus, the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device will be analyzed numerically based upon the FEM code ANSYS/Emag in this paper. In Section 2, the structure and working principle of the electromagnetic device are introduced briefly. Then, in Section 3, the theory foundation for computing the electromagnetic force using FEM is derived and the program realization process in ANSYS is illustrated. Two examples are chosen to verify the accuracy of the numerical method. Based upon these, in Section 4, the restoring force characteristics of the electromagnetic device with various DC coil currents are obtained utilizing the numerical method. Two important indicators (proportional coefficient between linear stiffness and coil current and linear range of the stiffness) are defined for measuring the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device. In the following section (Section 5), the effects of the design parameters (involving the electromagnetic and structural parameters) on the two indicators are discussed respectively. Finally, the conclusions are given in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. The electromagnetic device
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, the electromagnetic device consists of a pair of permanent magnets and a non-magnetic coil. The pair of magnets are fixed on support connected to the ground. An enamelled wire is wound around a plastic frame to form the coil. As the current flow through the coil, the coil becomes an electromagnet. The mutual acting forces between the electromagnet and the pair of magnets make the electromagnetic device function like a spring. When the DC coil current has the same direction as shown in Figure 1, the mutual acting forces between the electromagnet and the pair of magnets are repulsive forces. The resultant force acting on the electromagnet by the pair of magnets tends to push it back to the equilibrium position. In this case, the electromagnetic device has positive stiffness. When the DC coil current has the opposite direction to that shown in Figure 1, the mutual acting forces between the electromagnet by the pair of magnets are attractive forces. The resultant force tends to pull the electromagnet away from the equilibrium position. The electromagnetic device acts like a spring with negative stiffness. Since the non-contacting device possesses either the positive or negative stiffness, it can be employed to add or to remove stiffness from a structure without changing the structure. Figure 1.
Schematic of the electromagnetic device.

In addition, when the coil current is an AC current, the electromagnetic device becomes a spring with alternating stiffness. As the coil frame is plastic and non-ferromagnetic, there is no hysteresis for the stiffness changing with coil current. Moreover, the electromagnetic stiffness is linearly correlated to the coil current. Thus, the electromagnetic device could be used to produce parametric stiffness excitation, and the amplitude and frequency of the excitation are precisely and rapidly controlled by the coil current.

The structure and working principles of the electromagnetic device have been illustrated briefly. In the following section, a numerical method based upon ANSYS/Emag will be presented for analyzing the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device powered by a DC source.

sec.title: 3. Numerical method for the stiffness characteristics of electromagnetic device
sec.p: In this section, theory basis using a FEM for the electromagnetic force is derived, and the program realization process in ANSYS/Emag is introduced in brief. After that, two actual examples are selected to verify the accuracy of the numerical method.

sec.title: 3.1. Theory basis using a FEM for the electromagnetic force
3.1.1. (1) Scalar potential formulation for the magneto-static field
sec.p: Computing the mutual acting forces between the electromagnet and the pair of magnets belongs to the magnetostatic field problem. Magnetostatics means that time varying effects are ignored. This reduces Maxwell's equations for electromagnetic fields to: (1) (2) where ∇T represents the curl operator, and ∇T denotes the divergence operator; H and B are the magnetic field intensity vector and magnetic flux density vector, respectively; Js represents the applied source current density vector, which is related to the electromagnet.

In the magnetic field generated by the electromagnetic device, there are current source and permanent magnets, and no iron regions. Thus, introducing a generalized potential ψg and the field intensity Hs induced by the current source Js, a real magnetic field which satisfies Equation (1) is (Zienkiewicz et al. 1977) (3) in which ∇ represents the gradient operator, Hs satisfies the Biot–Savart's law and is obtained by evaluating the integral as (4) where r represents the position vector from current source to the node point and Vs is the volume of current source.

When the permanent magnet is considered, the constitutive relation becomes (5) where [μ] denotes the magnetic permeability matrix, and Hc is the coercive force vector of the permanent magnet. Substituting Equation (3) into Equation (5), and then into Equation (2), we have (6)

From Equation (6), it is shown that as long as the scalar potential ψg is computed, the magnetic intensity H and flux density B induced by the electromagnetic device with DC coil current could be ascertained using Equation (3) and (5). As the potential ψg is scalar, the magnetic field could be modeled discretely by a FEM (Zienkiewicz et al. 1977).

sec.p: The magnetic field caused by the electromagnetic device is modeled discretely by a FEM, and the nodal scalar potential is calculated utilizing Equation (12). Then, from Equation (3) and (9), the magnetic field intensity H is computed as (15) The magnetic flux density B could also be gained using the constitutive relation in Equation (5). Thus, the approximate magnetic coenergy in one element is (1984) (16) where Ve denotes volume of the element. Thus, the total electromagnetic force of the coil in the s direction Fs is (18)

Based on the above descriptions, the solution process for computing the electromagnetic force utilizing FEM involves four steps:
Step 1, the magnetic field intensity Hs induced by the current-carrying coil is obtained by evaluating the integral in Equation (4).
Step 2, the magnetic field is modeled discretely by FEM, and the coefficient matrix and external load vector of the system are computed and assembled using Equations (13) and (14). Then, the nodal scalar potential vector a is gained by solving the linear algebraic equations in Equation (12).
Step 3, the magnetic field intensity H and flux density B are computed utilizing Equations (15) and (5), respectively.
Step 4, the electromagnetic force acting on the coil is gained in virtue of the virtual work principle, as shown in Equations (17) and (18). The solution of the static electromagnetic force by the FEM code ANSYS/Emag follows the above-mentioned four steps generally.

sec.title: 3.2. Program realization in ANSYS
sec.p: The current source element (SOURC36) in ANSYS/Emag, used for modeling the current-carrying coil (electromagnet), does not support the two-dimensional analysis. Thus, the three-dimensional static electromagnetic analysis is chosen in ANSYS/Emag to model and compute the acting force of the coil by the permanent magnets. The corresponding program realization includes four parts.

sec.title: 3.2.1. (1) Definition of element types, real constants and material attributions
sec.p: The solid elements used in the three-dimensional static magnetic analysis are SOLID5, SOLID96 and SOLID98. SOLID5 and SOLID96 are bricks and have 8 nodes, while the SOLID98 is tetrahedral and has 10 nodes. Here, the SOLID98 is selected for its better precision.

Moreover, the current source element SOURC36 is utilized to model the electromagnet. There are three geometry types of the element: coil, bar and arc. Obviously, the coil type of SOURC36, as shown in Figure 2, is chosen in the analysis. In Figure 2, nodes I, J and K define the characteristic length, current flow direction and orientation of the element; CUR, DY and DZ are real constants, which represent the total current through source, characteristic y direction and characteristic z direction, respectively. Figure 2.
Geometry of the coil type of current source element SOURC36.

Because the plastic (the material of the coil frame) has a magnetic permeability close to air, it is approximated as air material in the analysis. Thus, the concerned material involves two types: air and permanent magnet. For the air material, the relative permeability is just specified as 1. In the case of the permanent magnet, requirements are the normal demagnetization curve (or relative permeability μr, if linear) and components of the magnetic coercive force Hc along the three orthogonal axes. In addition to the coercive force, there is another parameter of the permanent magnet, which is called the remanence Br. The relationship between the relative permeability and remanence is (19) in which μ0 = 4π × 10−7 is called the vacuum permeability.

sec.title: 3.2.2. (2) Establishment of the finite element model
sec.p: The establishment of the finite element model of the electromagnetic device is similar with that of the general structural analysis. Something that should be mentioned is that the surrounding air regions of the coil and permanent magnets should be expanded to an appropriate scope in order to reduce the error due to the leakage of magnetic flux. In order to compute the electromagnetic force, the air region of the coil is defined as a component.

sec.title: 3.2.3. (3) Application of boundary conditions and flags
sec.p: The boundary condition sets the value of magnetic flux density to be zero outside the expanding air region, namely that MAG = 0. The ANSYS macro command FMAGBC automates applying the flags on the coil component for calculating the electromagnetic force.

sec.title: 3.2.4. (4) Solution and post-processing
sec.p: For the scalar potential formulation of the static magnetic field, three solution strategies are provided in ANSYS: reduced scalar potential (RSP), difference scalar potential (DSP) and generalized scalar potential (GSP). As the finite element model of electromagnetic device does not contain the iron region, so the RSP strategy is recommended for the solution. After the solution of the static electromagnetic field, the force acting on the coil is calculated by the macro command FMAGSUM.

sec.title: 3.3. Validation
sec.p: The numerical method for analyzing the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device powered by DC current has been presented, including the theory foundation and program realization in ANSYS. In this section, specific examples are selected to validate the numerical method. Owing to the special structure of the electromagnetic device, two similar examples are found in current research. One is the magnetic field in a non-ferrous solenoid (Boast 1956), this example has a theoretical result. The other is the TEAM workshop problem 23 (force between a permanent magnet and an electromagnet) (Ida and Bastos 1996), which has been investigated experimentally.

sec.title: 3.3.1. (1) Magnetic field of a nonferrous solenoid
sec.p:
A non-ferrous solenoid is wound with one layer of No. 26 enamelled wire and carries a current. Its geometric sketch is shown in Figure 3. In the figure, s and r represent the length and cross-section radius of the solenoid; d denotes the diameter of the enamelled wire; l and h are the length and radius of the expanded air region for calculation, respectively. Table 1 lists the detailed geometric dimensions of the solenoid. Figure 3.
Geometry sketch of the non-ferrous solenoid. Table 1.

The number of turns of the solenoid is N = s/d = 231, and the current is I = 0.5 A. Therefore, the total current source is N × I = 115.5 A. Since no ferromagnetic materials are present, the field due to induced magnetization equals zero, and thus no scalar potential is required. The total magnetic field can be determined from the numerical integration of the coil source field upon specification of the coil with the current source element (SOURC36). Since the field is symmetric, an arbitrary arc of 20° is chosen with an additional symmetry plane taken along the coil midspan. The finite element model of the solenoid is plotted in Figure 4. The calculated magnetic flux density is shown in Figure 5. It is shown that the magnetic flux mostly distribute in the internal region of the coil, and the direction is from the downside to the upside. According to the right-hand rules, the north pole of the solenoid is at the tip of the solenoid. Thus, from the qualitative point of view, the magnetic field result is correct. Figure 4.

(Boast Boast 1956) analytically determined the magnetic flux density of three points on the centerline: the center of the coil (point A in Figure 3), the end of the coil (point B) and the point 190.5 mm from the center of the coil (point C). The result by ANSYS is also computed and compared with these analytical one, as listed in Table 2. We can see that the result by ANSYS is in good agreement with the analytical one, and the maximum value of the relative difference is not exceeded 3%, indicating that using the numerical method to compute the static magnetic field is correct. sec.title: 3.3.2. (2) Force between permanent magnets and electromagnets
sec.p:
This example is selected from one of the T.E.A.M. problems, where the experimental setup is shown in Figure 6 (Ida and Bastos 1996). In the experiment, the axial forces between magnet and non-magnetic coil were tested with various axial displacement at a fixed current of 50 mA. Two types of sizes, called the large magnet/coil and small magnet/coil, were used in the test. The geometric dimensions are listed in Table 3. Here l and h are also the length and radius of the expanded air region for calculation, respectively. The material of permanent magnet is samarium–cobalt, whose coercive force and remanence at room temperature (about 20° C or 68° F) are Hc = 7.20 × 105 A m−1 and Br = 1.02 T, respectively. The demagnetization curve for the magnet is assumed to be linear and the number of coil turns is 280. Figure 6.

The length and radius of the expanded air region are l = 3 × d2 and h = 8 × (δ + 1.524 + 0.127 × 2 + w). The axial forces between the magnet and electromagnet under various axial displacements are computed respectively utilizing the numerical method. sec.title: 4. Restoring force characteristics of the electromagnetic device
sec.p: In the previous section, a numerical method for analyzing the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device based upon ANSYS has been presented and verified through two typical examples. In this section, the restoring force characteristics of the electromagnetic device powered by a DC coil current are studied utilizing the numerical method. Then, two important indicators, the stiffness/current proportional coefficient and the linear range of stiffness, are introduced for measuring the electromagnetic stiffness.

sec.title: 4.1. Finite element model of the electromagnetic device
sec.p:
Figure 9 gives the geometry of the electromagnetic device and the north–south poles of the permanent magnet for computation. In the figure, dm and hm are the diameter and length of the permanent magnet; dc denotes the inner diameter of the coil frame; wc and hc represent the width and length of the wire winding in the coil; dce is the equivalent diameter of the coil, and dce = dc + wc. The space between the two magnets is denoted as H; Re and He are the radius and length of the expanded air region in computation, respectively. Figure 9.
Geometry sketch of the electromagnetic device.

The displacement of the coil from the center of the two magnets is denoted as z, and the up displacement is prescribed to be positive. Opposite to the provision of displacement direction, the down electromagnetic force of the coil is set to be positive. In addition, for the positive coil current, the north pole of the electromagnet is up and the south pole is down. When the coil current is negative, the south pole of the coil is up and the north pole is down. Obviously, the current direction in Figure 9 makes the north pole of the electromagnet up. In this case, the electromagnetic device has positive stiffness. The range of coil current is I ∈ [−2, 2] A, and the diameter of the wire (including insulation) is 0.0006 m. The number of turns is 36 and the winding type of coil (turns per layer and number of layers) is 6–6. Thus, the width and length of the wire winding are wc = hc = 0.0036 m. The type of permanent magnet is NdFeB, of which the magnetic coercive force and the remanence at room temperature are Hc = 8.68 × 105 A m−1 and Br = 1.17 T, respectively. The other geometric dimensions of the electromagnetic device are listed in Table 4. The equivalent coil diameter dce is calculated as 0.0364 m. Since the electromagnetic device is symmetric, the 1/18 sector of finite element model is established and shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
The 1/18 sector of the finite element model of the electromagnetic device. Table 4.

sec.title: 4.2. Restoring force characteristics
sec.p:
As the coil is powered by DC current with different values (I = −2, −1.5, −1, −0.5, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2 A), restoring force (the resultant force acting on the coil due to the two magnets) values of the electromagnetic device varying with coil displacement are plotted in Figure 11, respectively. In the figure, positive values of coil current correspond to restoring force curves with positive slopes. For a certain value of coil current, such as I = 2 A, the restoring force value becomes larger with the increase in displacement. Different coil current value makes the force changing rate different. Generally, the higher the coil current, the faster the changing rate. In the following, the relationship between the coil current and the changing rate of the restoring force with displacement will be investigated using the polynomial fitting technique. Figure 11.
Restoring force values changing with coil displacement for the electromagnetic device under various DC currents.

The restoring forces changing with displacement in Figure 11 are discrete data points. The continuous variation could be seen in virtue of the polynomial fitting technique. Taking the case of I = 2 A as an example, the polynomial fitting curves of degree one (linear) and three (cubic) for the restoring force data are plotted in Figure 12, respectively. It is shown that the cubic polynomial fitting provides a good approximation to the restoring force data. The linear polynomial fitting results meet the precision requirement for the coil in small displacement, while larger errors are produced for the coil in larger displacement. Figure 12.
Polynomial fitting results for the restoring forces changing with displacement for coil current equal to 2 A.

The electromagnetic stiffness is defined as the increase of restoring force per unit of coil displacement. From Figure 12, it is found that the stiffness of the electromagnetic device is linear in small coil displacement. However, nonlinear phenomena will occur for the electromagnetic stiffness in relative larger coil displacement. In actual practice, the electromagnetic stiffness should be working in linear range as soon as possible to avoid the nonlinear effect. In the paper, the coefficient of the first degree of the polynomial fitting function is taken as the linear stiffness, and its range is defined as the displacement in which the relative difference between the linear and cubic polynomial fitting results is no more than 5%. The linear range is shown as the range of the two verticals in Figure 12, corresponding to the displacements zr1 and zr2. Owing to the symmetry of the force in up and down displacements from the equilibrium position, zr2 = −zr1. In the following analysis, zr2 is chosen as the linear range of the electromagnetic stiffness.

Figure 13 plots the linear stiffness and its range of the electromagnetic device changing with the DC coil current, respectively. From Figure 13(a), we can see that the stiffness of the device is linearly proportional to the coil current. The linear electromagnetic stiffness is denoted by k (units: N m−1), then we have (20) in which a is the current/stiffness proportional coefficient (units: (N m−1) A−1). Here a characterizes the relationship between the linear stiffness and coil current. Under the same coil current, greater coefficient a could bring larger electromagnetic stiffness. It is indicated that the ability of the electromagnetic device to obtain additional stiffness is increasing. In addition, Figure 13(b) shows that there is no significant change for the linear stiffness range under different coil currents, which maintains about 0.0024 m. Therefore, it is concluded that the coil current has no effect upon the linear stiffness range. Figure 13.
Linear stiffness and its range changing with the DC coil current: (a) linear stiffness; (b) the range of linear stiffness.

Based upon the above discussions, the current/stiffness proportional coefficient and linear stiffness range are utilized as two indicators for measuring the stiffness characteristics of the device. In the following section, the effects of the design parameters (including structural and electromagnetic parameters) of the device upon the two indicators will be investigated, respectively.

sec.title: 5. Effects of design parameters upon stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device
sec.p: The structural parameters of the electromagnetic device are the diameter and length of the permanent magnet, the equivalent coil diameter, and the spacing between two magnets. The dimensions of the magnet should adhere to the market specifications. Here, the diameter and length of the magnet is fixed and the values are the same with these in the previous section. The electromagnetic parameters are the magnetic coercive force and the remanence of permanent magnet, number of turns of the coil and winding types of the coil.

Thus, the equivalent coil diameter and spacing between two magnets will be respectively considered in Sections 5.1 and 5.2. The coercive force and the remanence belong to the magnetic parameters of the permanent magnet, which are discussed in Section 5.3. The effects of number of turns and winding types of the coil are investigated in Sections 5.4 and 5.5.

sec.title: 5.1. Equivalent coil diameter
sec.p:
Practically, the equivalent coil diameter could be changed by adjusting the inner diameter of coil frame. The magnets spacing is fixed to be H = 0.012 m and the other parameters are the same with these in Section 4.2. As the equivalent coil diameter dce is in the range of [0.025, 0.055] m, Figure 14 shows the changes of the current/stiffness proportional coefficient a and linear stiffness range zr2, respectively. It is found from Figure 14(a) that the value of a first increases then decreases for the dce adding from 0.025 to 0.055 m. The maximal value is obtained as dce = 0.040 m, which just equals the magnet diameter. Figure 14.
The current/stiffness proportional coefficient and linear stiffness range changing with the coil equivalent diameter in the range of [0.025, 0.055] m: (a) proportional coefficient; (b) linear stiffness range.

Thus, the effect of the equivalent coil diameter upon the proportional coefficient is summarized as when the equivalent coil diameter is equal or near to the magnet diameter, the proportional coefficient achieves greater value, indicating that the electromagnetic device could have higher spring stiffness under the same coil current. If the difference (both greater than and less than) between the equivalent coil diameter and the magnet diameter is larger, the proportional coefficient would have lower value. In this case, same coil current could only bring lower stiffness to the electromagnetic device.

From Figure 14(b), we can see that changing the equivalent coil diameter also produces a significant impact on the linear stiffness range. In the case of dce = 0.040 m, the corresponding zr2 ≈ 0.0018 m, which is almost the minimum value, indicating that the largest proportional coefficient and widest linear stiffness range could not be obtained together. Increasing (or decreasing) dce from 0.040 m to 0.055 m (or 0.025 m) all makes zr2 first raise evidently and then fall gently. There are two ‘best’ diameters, corresponding to point B or point B′ in Figure 14(b), at which the zr2 reaches the maximal value, roughly equals to the air gap ((H − hc)/2 = 0.0042 m) between the coil and one of two magnets. This means that the electromagnetic device would have linear stiffness in all of movable range of the coil.

In order to explain the existence of two ‘best’ equivalent coil diameters for linear stiffness range, Figure 15 shows the restoring force curves for the electromagnetic device at points A, B, C, A′, B′, and C′ in Figure 14(b) with coil current I = 2 A. The solid and dashed lines in the figure represent the restoring force and the corresponding linear polynomial fitting curves, respectively. Figure 15.
Restoring force and the corresponding linear fitting curves for the device at six points in Figure 1(b): (a) point A; (b) point B; (c) point C; (d) point C′; (e) point B′; and (f) point A′.

For the equivalent coil diameter smaller than the diameter of point B or larger than the diameter of point B′, such as the diameter of point A or point A′ (as shown in Figure 15(a) or (f)), the varying rate of the restoring force is reducing in case of large coil displacement, showing that the stiffness of the electromagnetic device has the ‘soft’ feature. When the coil equivalent diameter is greater than the diameter of point B and less than the diameter of point B′, such as the diameter of point C or point C′ (as shown in Figure 15(c) or (d)), the varying rate of the restoring force is increasing for large coil displacement, indicating that the electromagnetic device has the ‘hard’ feature. As the coil equivalent diameter is increasing or decreasing from the magnet diameter (equal to 0.040 m), the electromagnetic stiffness will be gradually transformed from the ‘hard’ to ‘soft’ features. Therefore, there must be two values of equivalent coil diameter, one is larger than and the other is smaller than the magnet diameter, which cause the electromagnetic stiffness to be in the transition state. In this case, the device has the maximal value of linear stiffness range. For the equivalent coil diameter equals to the diameter of point B or point B′, as shown in Figure 15(b) or (e), either the soft or hard feature is not found in the restoring force curves, indicating that the device stiffness is around the transition state. Thus, the maximal value of linear stiffness range is obtained.

The equivalent coil diameter should be equal to or close to the magnet diameter by adjusting the inner diameter of the coil frame in order to obtain higher value of electromagnetic stiffness. However, the linear stiffness range is relatively small for this case. If the electromagnetic stiffness is expected to be linear in a larger range, then one part of the stiffness value will be sacrificed and the equivalent coil diameter should be designed to be any one of two certain values (one is larger than and the other is smaller than the magnet diameter). In addition, the stiffness and its linear range of the electromagnetic device all would be small as the equivalent coil diameter is too large or too small compared with the magnet diameter. This type of design should be avoid in actual practice if there is no special requirement.

sec.title: 5.2. Spacing between two magnets
sec.p:
The effect of spacing between two magnets H upon the stiffness characteristics of the device is discussed in this section. Three values of H (0.008, 0.01 and 0.012 m) are considered in the analysis, and Figure 16 shows the proportional coefficient a and linear stiffness range zr2 changing with the equivalent coil diameter dce, respectively. Figure 16.
The effect of the magnet distance upon the stiffness characteristics: (a) proportional coefficient; (b) linear stiffness range.

For different values of H, the qualitative properties of the electromagnetic stiffness changing with dce are similar with the above descriptions. In quantitative aspect, when the equivalent coil diameter is equal to or close to the magnet diameter, reducing the magnet distance increases the current/stiffness proportional coefficient evidently and the increasing rate is accelerated, as shown in Figure 16(a). For dce = 0.040 m and H = 0.012 m, the corresponding proportional coefficient is a = 180 (N m−1) A−1. As H is reduced to 0.010 m, the value of a is increased to 220 (N m−1) A−1 and the increment is 40 (N m−1) A−1. Continuing to reduce H to 0.008 m, the value of a reaches 300 (N m−1) A−1 and the increment is 80 (N m−1) A−1, which is obviously greater than the increment of a from H = 0.012 to 0.010 m. In addition, if there is large difference between the equivalent coil diameter and the magnet diameter (both greater than and less than), changing the magnet distance seems to have little effect on the proportional coefficient of the electromagnetic device.

Figure 16(b) shows that reducing the magnet distance decreases the linear stiffness range with varying degrees. For dce equal to or close to the magnet diameter, the electromagnetic stiffness has ‘hard’ features and the value of zr2 is slightly decreased due to the reduction of H. When dce is far from the magnet diameter, the electromagnetic stiffness would have the ‘soft’ feature or be in a transition state, the value of zr2 is notably decreased for reducing the H.

The above discussion shows that: adjusting the spacing between two magnets is an effective way for the stiffness design of the electromagnetic device. In the premise of the equivalent coil diameter close to the magnet diameter, reducing the magnet spacing increases the stiffness of the electromagnetic device with the same coil current, while the linear stiffness range would be decreased in this case. Moreover, the air gap between the coil and one of the two magnets is reducing along with the magnet spacing, which would also narrow the actual moveable range of the coil. These factors should be considered comprehensively in the practical design.

sec.title: 5.3. Magnetic coercive force and remanence of the permanent magnet
sec.p: The magnetic parameters of the permanent magnet are the coercive force Hc and remanence Br. In this section, they are analyzed respectively for their impacts on the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device.

The magnet spacing is H = 0.012 m, and the remanence is fixed to be Br = 1.17 T. Three values of the magnetic coercive force (Hc = 7.56 × 105, 8.68 × 105 and 9.47 × 105 A m−1) are considered in analysis, and the computational results for both the current/stiffness proportional coefficient a and linear stiffness range zr2 changing with the equivalent coil diameter dce are plotted in Figure 17, respectively. For certain equivalent coil diameter, Figure 17(a) shows that adding the coercive force increases the proportional coefficient, especially for the coil equivalent diameter close to the magnet diameter. Thus, the stiffness of the electromagnetic device could be enhanced by increasing the magnetic coercive force. In addition, it is found from Figure 17(b) that changing the coercive force almost has no effect upon the linear stiffness range. Figure 17.
The effect of the magnetic coercive force upon the stiffness characteristics: (a) proportional coefficient; (b) linear stiffness range.

The magnetic coercive force is fixed to be Hc = 8.68 × 105 A m−1, the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device with three values of the remanence (Br = 1.04, 1.17 and 1.45 T) are shown in Figure 18. With adding the value of remanence, the proportional coefficient is increased, indicating that same coil current could bring greater stiffness for the electromagnetic device. It is found from in Figure 18(b) that changing remanence has a little influence upon the linear stiffness range Figure 18.
The effect of the remanence upon the stiffness characteristics: (a) proportional coefficient; (b) linear stiffness range.

The above discussion is summarized as follows: increasing the magnetic parameters (both coercive force and remanence) of the permanent magnet will all enhance the ability of the electromagnetic device to gain greater stiffness values. Moreover, the linear stiffness range is not affected by the magnetic parameters.

sec.title: 5.4. Number of turns of the coil
sec.p:
Here, the number of turns of the coil is taken into account in the discussion. The diameter of the wire and the turns per layer are the same as in Section 4.2. Thus, the change in coil turns is achieved by adjusting the number of layers of the winding wire. The magnet spacing is fixed to be H = 0.012 m. Three values of the number of turns of the coil (24, 36 and 48) are concerned in the analysis. Then, the current/stiffness proportional coefficient and linear stiffness range varying with the equivalent coil diameter are plotted in Figure 19, respectively. Figure 19.
The effect of the number of turns of the coil upon the stiffness characteristics: (a) proportional coefficient; (b) linear stiffness range.

From Figure 19(a), we can see that the proportional coefficient is increased evidently by adding the number of coil turn, especially for an equivalent coil diameter close to the magnetic diameter. Figure 19(b) shows that the linear stiffness range is slightly widened with the increase in the number of turns of the coil. With the same equivalent coil diameter, adding the number of turns of the coil would significantly enhance the ability of the device to obtain electromagnetic stiffness. However, the coil weight is increasing along with the number of turns of the coil, which should be considered in the stiffness design of the electromagnetic device by changing the turn number of the coil.

sec.title: 5.5. Winding type of the coil
sec.p:
In the premise of the ascertained wire diameter and number of turns, the winding type of the coil (turns per layer and number of layers) should be regarded in the design practice. Actually, various winding types make the dimensions of the length and width of winding wire change, which indeed have impacts upon the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device. If we give the number of coil turns as 36, five winding types are concerned in the analysis, and the corresponding length and width dimensions of winding wire are listed in Table 5, respectively. The magnet spacing is set to be H = 0.012 m. With five winding types, the current/stiffness proportional coefficient and linear stiffness range varying with the equivalent coil diameter are plotted in Figure 20, respectively. Figure 20.

When the equivalent coil diameter is close to the magnet diameter, Figure 20(a) shows that the coil of ‘12–3’ has the maximal proportional coefficient, the others are smaller and the smallest proportional coefficient corresponds to the coil of ‘3–12’. If the equivalent coil diameter is largely different to the magnet diameter, the proportional coefficients of five winding types are almost the same. For certain magnet distances and numbers of turns, the coil with larger length and smaller width of winding wire would have greater stiffness in the same coil current. As shown in Figure 20(b), the maximal value of linear stiffness range corresponds to the coil of ‘3–12’, while the others are lower and the coil of ‘12–3’ has the lowest value. It is indicated that the coil with smaller length and larger width of winding wire has roughly greater values of linear stiffness range.

Therefore, we can say that the linear stiffness range could be reduced due to the increasing the length and decreasing the width of the winding wire. However, for certain magnet spacing and number of turns, the moveable range of the coil (the air gap between the coil and one of the two magnets) is reducing with the increase in the length of winding wire. This should be taken into account in the actual design.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p:
A numerical method, based upon the commercial FEM package ANSYS/Emag, has been presented for analyzing the stiffness characteristics of the electromagnetic device powered by the DC coil current. The theory foundation for the method is derived, and the program realization in ANSYS is introduced briefly. Then, two typical examples are chosen to verify the accuracy of the numerical method. After these, the restoring force characteristics of the device with various coil current are obtained by utilizing the numerical method, and two indicators, the current/stiffness proportional coefficient and linear stiffness range, are defined to measure the linear stiffness characteristics. The design parameters (both structural and electromagnetic parameters) have been investigated for their effects upon the two indicators. The conclusions are summarized as follows:
The stiffness of the device is linearly proportional to the coil current. The linear stiffness range is not affected by the current.
When the equivalent coil diameter is equal to or close to the magnet diameter, the electromagnetic device could have greater value of stiffness with the same coil current. If the electromagnetic stiffness is required to operate linearly in a wide range, the equivalent coil diameter is recommended to be any one of the two ‘best’ diameters, which means that the electromagnetic stiffness is in transition state.
In addition to the equivalent coil diameter, the spacing between two magnets is also an important structural parameter for the stiffness design of the electromagnetic device. For the equivalent coil diameter close to the magnet diameter, decreasing the magnet spacing could effectively enhance the ability to obtain greater stiffness for the device. However, the linear stiffness range is reduced along with the magnet spacing decreasing.
The magnetic parameters (both the coercive force and remanence) of the permanent magnet would slightly affect the electromagnetic stiffness, while they almost have no effect upon the linear stiffness range.
For certain wire diameter and turns per layer, adding the number of turns of the coil will increase the electromagnetic stiffness evidently. However, the weight of the coil is also increased, which should be considered in the design practice.
For certain magnet spacing and number of turns, changing the winding type of the coil will affect the stiffness of the device. The coil with larger length and smaller width of winding wire would have greater stiffness and relatively narrower linear stiffness range.
